article.title: Signal Processing for Gigabit-Rate Wireline Communications

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 illustrate regarding the DSL channel?
choices: The detrimental effect of phase noise in DSL systems.
The superiority of 215 QAM in achieving high spectral efficiency.
The use of DMT to transform a broadband frequency selective channel into many frequency-flat narrowband channels.
The strong diagonal dominance of the DSL channel matrix at high frequencies.

multiple_choice_question.text: What are the system parameters for the G.fast system illustrated in Figure 2?
choices: K = 4096 tones, L = 750 samples, sampling frequency = 70 Msps.
K = 2048 tones, L = 320 samples, sampling frequency = 212 Msps.
K = 256 tones, L = 120 samples, sampling frequency = 48 KHz.
K = 4096 tones, L = 208 samples, sampling frequency = 400 Msps.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 depict regarding the DSL binder?
choices: The DSL binder acts as a multiple access channel in both the upstream and downstream.
The DSL binder experiences only FEXT and eliminates NEXT due to the twisted pair structure.
FEXT and NEXT represent the direct path and coupled signals respectively.
The DSL binder acts as a multiple access channel in the upstream and a broadcast channel in the downstream.

multiple_choice_question.text: What duplexing method is used in G.fast and how is it different from VDSL?
choices: Both G.fast and VDSL use FDD, separating upstream and downstream in the frequency domain.
G.fast uses TDD, separating upstream and downstream in the time domain, while VDSL uses FDD.
G.fast uses FDD, separating upstream and downstream in the frequency domain, while VDSL uses TDD.
Both G.fast and VDSL use TDD, separating upstream and downstream in the time domain.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 5 illustrate regarding vectored receive processing?
choices: Coordinated signal processing is applied at each CPE to reduce the effect of FEXT.
Signal coordination among CPEs enables joint transmit processing.
Received signals from all users are collected at the DP and processed jointly to reduce FEXT.
Each CPE decodes its signal independently without coordination, treating the binder as an interference channel.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does vectored transmit processing differ from vectored receive processing?
choices: Vectored transmit processing is only applicable in the upstream while vectored receive processing is for the downstream.
Vectored transmit processing involves pre-equalization at the DP to reduce FEXT, while vectored receive processing cancels FEXT at the receiver.
Vectored transmit processing relies on signal coordination among CPEs, while vectored receive processing does not.
Both vectored transmit and receive processing require a dedicated precoder at each CPE to cancel self-crosstalk.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which factors contribute to FEXT coupling as described in Formula (1)?
choices: Thermal noise, central frequency, and loop length.
Frequency, coupling length, and attenuation of the interfering signal.
Diagonal dominance, sampling frequency, and DMT symbol duration.
Cyclic prefix length, number of users, and bit loading.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the vector channel model in Formula (2) represent?
choices: The signal propagation over a single twisted pair, considering only thermal noise.
The impact of ISI on a broadband frequency selective channel.
The linear relationship between transmitted symbols, channel gains, and received signals, considering FEXT and noise.
The capacity of a DSL system under discontinuous operation.
